Hyperadrenocorticism, also known as Cushing's disease, is a condition in pets characterized by excessive production of the hormone cortisol. The most common clinical signs include increased thirst and urination, increased appetite, weight gain, muscle weakness, lethargy, and thinning of the skin - https://www.merckvetmanual.com/endocrine-system/the-pituitary-gland/cushing-disease-pituitary-dependent-hyperadrenocorticism-in-animals

Hyperadrenocorticism, also known as Cushing's disease, is a condition in pets characterized by excessive production of the hormone cortisol. The most common clinical signs include increased thirst and urination, increased appetite, weight gain, muscle weakness, lethargy, and thinning of the skin - https://www.merckvetmanual.com/endocrine-system/the-pituitary-gland/cushing-disease-pituitary-dependent-hyperadrenocorticism-in-animals
Affected pets may also exhibit excessive panting, pot-bellied appearance, and a dull, rough hair coat - https://www.medvet.com/cushings-disease-in-dogs/
Affected pets may also exhibit excessive panting, pot-bellied appearance, and a dull, rough hair coat - https://www.medvet.com/cushings-disease-in-dogs/
In some cases, dogs may experience alopecia (hair loss) and fragile skin that bruises easily - https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/treating-cushings-disease-dogs
In some cases, dogs may experience alopecia (hair loss) and fragile skin that bruises easily - https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/treating-cushings-disease-dogs

Cushing's disease occurs predominantly in older dogs, typically between 7 to 12 years of age. - https://www.merckvetmanual.com/endocrine-system/the-pituitary-gland/cushing-disease-pituitary-dependent-hyperadrenocorticism-in-animals
The condition is less common in cats, with only about 20-25% of feline cases being adrenocortical tumors that secrete excessive cortisol. - https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6559942/
This condition is characterized by excessive production of cortisol, a hormone produced by the adrenal glands. - https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6500859/

In the majority of cases, hyperadrenocorticism is caused by a tumor in the pituitary gland that secretes excessive amounts of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). - Cushing's Disease in Dogs (Hyperadrenocorticism): What Is It? https://veterinarypartner.vin.com/default.aspx?pid=19239&catId=254094&id=4951983

Screening and diagnostic tests are used to confirm the diagnosis. These may include the urine cortisol-to-creatinine ratio, low-dose dexamethasone suppression test, and ACTH stimulation test - The Diagnosis of Canine Hyperadrenocorticism: https://todaysveterinarypractice.com/endocrinology/the-diagnosis-of-canine-hyperadrenocorticism/

The primary treatment for hyperadrenocorticism (Cushing's disease) in dogs is medical management with mitotane (op'-DDD; Lysodren) - Treatment of Canine Hyperadrenocorticism - WSAVA2011 - VIN
Trilostane is also a commonly used medication for treating hyperadrenocorticism in both dogs and cats - Feline Hyperadrenocorticism/Hypercortisolism - AAHA
In addition to medication, supportive care and nursing management are important - Update on Managing Canine Hyperadrenocorticism - ISVMA
Melatonin has also been used as a first-line treatment, especially for cases with alopecia, as it has few side effects - Treatment Considerations - University of Tennessee

attr.risks: adrenal insufficiency if done too quickly
